# C4: Complete Cognitive Coordinate System

> Adaptive Routing Theory: From Cognitive Coordinates to Combinatorial Optimization

A formal framework modeling cognition as navigation through a 27-element state space Z3^3, structured by three orthogonal axes: Time (Past/Present/Future), Scale (Concrete/Abstract/Meta), and Agency (Self/Other/System). The framework includes 11 core theorems (10 verified in Agda) and a cross-domain application to combinatorial optimization via the MASTm (Multi-scale Adaptive Spectral TSP meta-solver).

The name "C4" encodes multiple layers: CCCS abbreviation, combinatorial explosion "detonation", completeness claim (Koan of Awakening), and the hidden 4th dimension. See WHY-C4.md for details.

Most content is available in both English and Russian (bilingual repository).

## Central Thesis

Any system that fingerprints its input, routes execution to a matched strategy, and adapts based on feedback will outperform any fixed strategy over sufficiently diverse inputs. Intelligence can be modeled as adaptive routing through structured state space.

## Key Concepts

- Z3^3: finite Abelian group of 27 cognitive states with Hamming distance metric
- Adaptive Routing Theorem: fingerprint-route-adapt protocol proven superior to fixed strategies
- MASTm: Multi-scale Adaptive Spectral TSP meta-solver (0.22% gap on fl3795)
- Agda Verification: 10 of 11 theorems machine-checked via dependent types
- Universal Fingerprint Protocol: domain-independent strategy selection mechanism
- Cross-domain universality: same pattern across optimization, NLP, decision-making, cognitive science
- **Hypothesis ID-3 (CONFIRMED)**: intrinsic dimensionality of cognitive text embeddings â‰ˆ 3.0 (95% CI: [2.91, 3.15] at N=5000), validated across 3 models, 2 languages. Hamming distance in Z3^3 predicts confusion (r=-0.489). Axis hierarchy: Scale >> Agency >> Time
- **FRA Scaling (VALIDATED)**: FRA routing achieves +44% over SBS on SAT11-RAND (diversity 78%). Key finding: K_min = n_types (step function). Wilcoxon p=0.0002. See experiments/fra_scaling_v2/
